bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, July 27, 1875

div1.p: Reed describes to Emilie Lawrence the difficulties he undergoes to reach his army post at Willets Point, New York harbor.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, July 27, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
July 27th, 1875.

div1.p:
I am, once more,
upon my “native heath,” and
have taken the first opportunity
of writing to you. In my last, writ-
ten from the Cosmopolitan Hotel,
I promised to write on Monday,
but when Monday came, I found
so many matters requiring my
attention that I was compelled
to forego the pleasure. Let me
give you a brief outline of
my meandering since I wrote.
Sunday afternoon, I visited
Pier 1, East River, intending to
embark for Govenor's Is-
land, in order to see our
friend, Dr Hoff. On reaching the
Steamboat, however, I found that
Dr H. no longer resided on the Is-
land, so that I had to trudge back
to my Hotel, fruitless. In vain,I
tried to find some way by
which I could reach my Post.
Thinking that I might get some
information in Brooklyn, I went
over the same afternoon & called
on my old doctor-friends at the
City Hospital- They received
me cordially -- in fact “knew
me from afar,” and “ran to”
me, but did not “fall on
my neck,” probably because they
knew that I did not allow such
familiarities. Notwithstanding
their friendship, they could not
tell me how I could reach
Willet's Point- After spending
a few pleasant hours with
them, swaying to & fro, under a
green elm, in a hammock,
I returned to my hotel- After
supper, went again to Brooklyn
to see my friends Mr & Mrs. Deck-
er, No. 235 G. 9th st., where I
used to board, you'll remember-
They were very glad to see me
& insisted upon my spending
the night with them -- said
they would put my old room at my
my service & treat me to a
nice breakfast. To all of these
entreaties,however, I turned
a deaf ear, but they would
not let me leave till I had
promised to make their house
my headquarters whenever
I came to the city. I returned
from Brooklyn about 9.30
P.M. & as I crossed the E. Riv-
er, what do you suppose
do I saw? I was standing on
the forward deck, the night was
very bright & the Heavens beau-
tiful. Now what do you think
would attract my attention at
such a time? Who do you suppose
claimed my thoughts? Ah! you
sweet little angel! 'Twas
Jupiter that attracted my gaze
& of you I thought- There I
was, floating between two
giant cities -- a mighty tum-
ult all around me; but
in the midst of these discor-
dant sounds, my thoughts were
500 miles away & I only saw
your sweet face, & heard the
your gentle voice!

But I must hasten on--
Early yesterday morning, I
repaired to Army Headquar-
ters & there learned that I could
take the North Shore R.R. of
Long Island & come to a
town called Whitestone, only
3 miles from the Post. I there
heard also that my good
friend Dr Torney had been
stationed at Fort Wood
N.Y. Harbor & was stopping
at the Stephens Hotel- You
should have seen how I
“rushed frantically” forth
& with a voice of thunder
hailed the first stage- In
a short time I was at the
Stephens Hotel, but just in
time to be too late- Dr T. had
just paid hiss bill & gone
to his post- I bewailed my
fate & wended my way
quickly to my Hotel. I will
see the Dr in a few days, as
he is stationed very near
the city. After dinner, I went
out & had my baggage checked,
and took a hack for James'
slip, & thence by boat to
Hunter's Point, L.I. City,&
from there to Whitestone by
rail- At the latter place, I
met the Senior Surgeon of the
Post & rode out with him-
He is very pleasant & I
am especially glad of it, as
I am quartered in the same
house with him. At dinner
(6.P.M.) I met two Captains & 2
second lieutenants- They, with
the surgeon & myself, form
what is known as the “bach-
elor” mess- I must confess
that I do not like the term,
as it implies that I am an
old bachelor, a thing which
I never intend to be. We had
a good supperDinner & I ate hear-
tily- After dinner, I went
to the Commanding Officer's
Residence, to report for duty-
(I had already donned my mil-
itaries, so as to make a
good appearance) Dr Byrne,
the Surgeon, escorted me, & I
was soon in the presence
of General Abbott. By the
way, I found him to be one
of the most pleasant gentle-
man I ever met with.

Leaving the General's house,
we visited the Hospital,
being saluted on the way
by about 40 soldiers-
You should have seen
me returning the salute.
I did it in grand style-
After seeing a few patients, I
returned to my residence & was
soon asleep- This morning, I
have been busy writing my
letters to the Surgeon General-
I am free to say that I am more
than pleased with my post &
only hope that I can remain
here the remainder of the year.
In my next letter, I'll give you
a description of the post, etc.
I forgot to say that we have
a most excellent band of music
which plays 3 times a day.
As soon as I heard it, last
night, I thought of you! would
that I could send you a few
of its strains!

Will write again on Thursday.
Answer as soon as you get
this -- Address Dr W. Reed, U.S.A.
Willet's Point, N.Y. Harbor, & believe me
div1.closer:
fondly & devotedly, yours, Walter. Kind regards to all your family, including the Dr & wife,
Your mother, Mrs. Harrell etc-
